Description: Fragment of painted limestone relief: showing part of an offering table, with meat, grapes and bread, against a pale blue background. The scene and text are carved, with details being added in paint (such as the stalk of the bunch of grapes). There is a hieroglyphic caption in a vertical line; the signs face left, the same direction as the royal figure making the offering, remains of whose kilt and hands holding a vessel survive. Above the offering table are traces of numbers, in a tabulated list, recording the offerings.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr Harry Reginald Holland Hall
Curator's comments: Such scenes on temple walls representing the temple ritual enacted the reciprocity of divine and human embodied in the king that was essential to maintaining the cosmos. Cultic service was the symbolic prerogative of the king, and was shown as such, but the daily practice was different. Bibliography: J.H. Taylor & D. Antoine, Ancient Lives New Discoveries, London 2014, p. 40
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (6)
